reviewText:
*Artwork/Animation: 10/10
-Artwork: this is a 2D pixel game which is super cute and done well.
-Animations: The animations are done nicely and I haven't experienced any glitches. The only thing I did notice is you do have to be positioned in the correct spot in order to collect things such as blood samples. For example, say you walk up to a blood splatter on the ground. If you're on the left of the pile of blood and use the spacebar or enter button to interact with the object, nothing will happen. However, if you're standing in front of the pool of blood then use the interaction buttons, you'll collect the sample. This is minor but could still be improved.

*Sound: 8/10
I couldn't tell if there was background music or not because it was so faint! The sound for entering and leaving buildings was weird and when dialog took place no one talked. It was all reading. There is a point in the game you have to listen to a recording, this part the voice actor did a nice job and I liked that you could read along to what he was saying.

*Hours to complete: 8/10
I beat chapter one within 44 minutes. I did have to listen to the sheriff's recording again though (which you can't skip unfortunately) and that's about 2-3 minutes long. So if you don't make that mistake you can easily beat it within 40 minutes. I gave it an 8/10 score only because I wish it was a little longer! I really enjoyed playing it and I'm not sure when the next chapter will be released!

*Story Line: 10/10
You play as two detectives from out of state and travel to Silver Creek Falls (which is a real place, btw) to learn about a recent mystery case that has troubled the local police department. You must investigate 3 different crime scenes to help unfold the mystery located in this small town.

*Game Play: 10/10
I had such a fun time playing this game. I love 2D pixel games. It reminds me of my childhood. From the moment I started playing, I was intrigued and entertained. My inner detective was constantly trying to figure out what could have happened to this town. Before you play there is a note in the beginning to let you know to keep your eyes out for anything that could be used for evidence. This actually did help me because I literally checked every room, locker, shelf, etc I could and found things that could have been easily missed. I collected every blood sample (43 total, which is one of the steam achievements. The other is to drink one of the blood samples) and any other evidence I could find. At the very end of the game I never suspected what happened and I'm still very confused because even the cliff hanger didn't give any information and left me with more questions! I want more of this game!!

*Price: 10/10
The best part: as of right now, the game is free to play!! I would easily pay up to $10 for this game with more chapters being available and/or being released quickly. So get it while you can!

*Overall:
I would recommend this game to anyone who likes:
>2D pixel games
>Detective/mystery games
>Short, casual games
>Chapter/story games

**Note: This review was made for CHAPTER ONE.

reviewText:
Silver Creek Falls - Chapter 1 is a free-to-play game, destined to promote the two next episodes. However, there is a DLC that you can buy, which is the soundtrack. You know how Steam is working with F2P or free games: once uninstalled, they're not showing in your library anymore. The only way to keep them listed is to buy a DLC - many F2P propose packages, soundtracks or extras. I've bought the DLC, only to keep it in my library. But it's not a useless purchase: I loved the soundtrack.

You're Sara Fitzgerald, a detective partnered with a foreign man, sent to Silver Creek Falls to investigate a series of bloody murders. However, what you will find there is bigger than the simple result of a serial killer.

The plot is interesting and is meant to be expanded in the next games. I'm in the middle of the second chapter and the third one is being released at the end of March 2016. Right now, the story is holding up its promise.

The game is also using RPG Maker, however, it's an adventure game, so, you have nothing to upgrade or to level up. The controls are good but I got an hard time to get used to them, mainly with the inventory. I missed a tutorial in the game. Compared to Space Pilgrim, it was less intuitive.

The fact that it's a RPG Maker game didn't bother me, I found the graphics very acceptable, besides, given the fact that the first chapter is bloody, you're not going to find any fairy tale. However, the achievements coming with the game is very explicit: find all blood samples and drink one of them... I don't know if there is a link to vampires but it's sure saying something: you're not here to have cute characters, cute crime scenes or a cute world. The game is set in our modern era, so, don't expect futuristic buildings or castles... Expect houses, warehouses or streets that are very common.

I would say that given the fact that the game took only a half-hour to be beaten, it's nice to have released as a free game. However, after some thinking, I wouldn't have minded to spend 1 euro/dollar on it, just to support the developers. It wouldn't hurt at all. However, as they've released the soundtrack, I've given that euro/dollar to them by buying it.

Silver Creek Falls is a promising game. I mean by that that the next chapters should be interesting - I can say that the second chapter is quite intriguing. As for chapter three, it's Wait and See" as it will be released soon. Given the fact that the game is free

TL;DR: The first chapter of an investigation and mystery game saga promises an intriguing story line but lacks in its potentially coolest features.

RPGMaker game that is not an RPG, Silver Creek Falls puts you in the shoes of two police detectives who are presented with a case of ominous disappearances at the small town of Silver Creek Falls. I will try to keep this spoiler-free for the important bits, because the story is so short for the time being. Note that only chapters 1 and 2 are out. The third and last one will come in 2016.

The case presented is indeed ominous: large pools of blood are found at the scenes with no bodies to be found. What's going on? It's for your pair of investigators to find out. There are hints of occultism, secret societies and a shroud of mystery around the case. Gameplay consists of looking for evidence at the crime scenes and a couple of times you need to make minor deductions based on the evidence.

The deductions part could have been so much better executed. You are presented with a multiple-choice questions and got to choose the right answer based on the evidence. However, guessing wrong is not penalized, instead you get to try another answer right away. Being right straight on is not rewarded in any way either, rendering these deductions dull. It would have been cool if you were to chase the wrong lead for a few minutes: done right it could have sparked an additional story arc or at least a source of humour. Think about it: the investigators going to a café instead of the right scene, enjoying a coffee and finally realizing that Nope
date: there's no clues here. Where to next?" and then resume the story.\n\nAlso

reviewText:
It's tough to recommend this. It seems to serve as bait to get people to buy the other 2 chapters. They could've just as easy made it one complete game. I've seen massive RPGMaker games going for less than $5. To get the other 2 chapters of this story, it would cost $9.98. That's a bit much.

Unlike many of the other RPGMaker games, this one strays from the typical [J|A|C]RPG storylines and goes with a crime/investigation mystery story. It's fairly predictible most of the time, but that's okay. The genre tends to be that way for the most part unless the writer happens to be really good with setting up mysteries.

I haven't played the other 2, so I can't speak for the series as a whole, but this chapter is extremely linear. The map is very small, and each scene is limited. The only actions available are collecting things, examining prop items, talking to NPCs when required to continue, and entering/exiting a scene. They all must be followed in a given order. The characters aren't all that special, either.

The only reason it would take more than 15-30 minutes to complete is because of the extra fluff dialog, such as the history of the park. Or, in my case, you miss some things needed for the Dracula achievement, so the first scenes would need to be played again.

With all of this, I'm still recommending it.
It's free. I wishlisted the other 2 chapters for when they go on a steep sale in order for me to continue the story.
Easy achievements. For completionists like me, this is a good thing.
It's not just another JRPG. It doesn't even come close to being awesome like To The Moon, but it does bring something different to RPGMaker.
It's short. Yes, that's a plus in my book.
So, for it being free and short, you may as well give it a go if you have any interest in light mystery stories.

reviewText:
Playing as a pair of detectives on their first assignment after being freshly paired together, you must investigate the grisly murders that have befallen a small, sleepy town in the Southern States whilst also searching for the whereabouts of a missing person connected to the case. Investigation here basically involves examining and collecting blood at three different crime scenes as well as picking up any items littered throughout. It's all very minimal and arguably more focused on story over gameplay. Between that and its old school, top down, RPG aesthetics, it reminds me a lot of To the Moon, though without that particular masterpiece's nuance for a well-crafted and touching story.

I'd review this game positively, not because I'd necessarily recommend it exactly, but more because, while I personally found it largely forgettable and mostly a non-event, it feels pretty clear that it was made with sincere intent that means well and wants to pay respect and homage to the inspirations that informed it. That and because, being free, there's nothing to lose by anyone interested in it who has an hour to kill. Though I would warn that there are some aspects that may potentially bother, like the fact it can only be played in a very small window with no options to adjust anything, and the only controls of any meaningful use are the arrows keys to move and the Enter key to examine or use items.

Given that it has Chapter 1" in its title it should come as no surprise that a follow-up is also available

reviewText:
Interesting game, but the dialog is rough, and a bit immature for the characters involved. Who says 'Cool!' when asked to investigate a crime scene?

The voice acted bit was...Hm. Well, the accent was far too 'Southern Belle' when it should have been more 'Decorated Lawman'. I was honestly reminded of Tommy Lee Jones' portrayal of Clay Shaw in 1991's JFK. While Jones' performance was stellar...the accent does NOT fit this kind of character. Also, I find if difficult to believe that the Sheriff would leave a cryptic sounding note for HIMSELF. If it were re-worded to be intentionally listened to by a third party from the beginning instead of at the tail end it would have been easier to suspend disbelief.

Also, there are far too many contradictions to the story to be believable. You have a Sheriff who takes detailed notes on the crime scene, photos, etc...but leaves key pieces of evidence at the scenes? A deputy who didn't bother to even gather evidence because 'we don't have the facilities?'

I dunno...there's a lot of potential, and FREE is a nice price, but the continuity and plot errors of the game are glaring, and in a story-heavy game that's almost unforgivable. Also...Sara or Sarah. PICK ONE.


TLDR: I'm recommending it, hesitantly, and only because it is free. It's a decent story game, but the plot hiccups and continuity errors are enough to sour your taste. And the VO scene is unintentionally hilarious.

I have to point out though, the voice acting work on the video tapes kind of hurt the atmosphere for me.  I'm not going to say the voice acting was bad or anything like that and I am not trying to, either.  But it just sort of halted the pace and took away from the feel of the game up to that point.

I was looking all over the place, unsure if I had finished them (not wanting to leave anything out at all, of course) so having the game leet you know when you had collected everything for sure, would be a nice touch.
